Ok. Seminary graduate here. Let's talk about 9D. The Hebrew name for God is not Yahweh. In fact, the Hebrew name for God is unpronounceable and, frankly, un-writeable. It's why many Jews write G-d instead of God; as a former teacher at a Jewish Day School, I encountered that pretty regularly. It is signified in Scripture as the tetragrammaton, YHWH, which is generally spoken as Adonai, which in English bible translations usually appears as "Lord." Yahweh is a Christian construction that forces vowel sounds into the tetragrammaton. The Latinized Jehovah does the same, importing the vowels of Adonai into the tetragrammaton. The Hebrew bible has many reasons for not rendering the name of God as utterable. So perhaps the NYT could respect that and simply clue YAHWEH as "Weird Christian effort to make the name of God pronounceable."

And yes, Deb, I too needed a refresher on how spoonerisms work. Who do I blame? In honor of the NYT's YAHWEH screw-up, I'm going to say the Roman Catholic Church.

Just to be clear, Yahweh is not a Hebrew name for God. At least not to Jews. From a religious standpoint, trying to pronounce the four-letter name is forbidden. So we say Adonai or Hashem, which allude to “The Name” but make no attempt to pronounce it. In an academic setting, Yahweh is used. But it feels tacky to me to have in a puzzle, which is not an academic forum.

One more late puzzle find. Don't recall another one like this either. A Thursday from November 1, 2018 by Matt Ginsberg. The theme answers included one square with a rebus consisting of two letters separated by a slash. So the actual implied answer was that answer repeated one after the other with that letter replaced. Example: P(I/A)TTER - (PITTER PATTER) GALILE(O/I) - (GALILEO GALILEI) (J/B)ELLY -- JELLYBELLY ASGO(O/L)D -- ASGOODASGOLD And there were more. Not really a joke, just a short story:
I am also somewhat inclined to accidentally speak in spoonerisms. When I was a senior in HS, my sister was planning her wedding. This was in the days before Bach parties and before gift registries weren't like letters to Santa Claus. In those days, the only things people usually registered were their selected patterns for sets such as fine china, crystal, or sterling silverware that were too expensive for one present. But it did make it more likely that a couple would get different presents that had the same function. In my sister's case, it seemed that someone suggested that everyone send her a set of salt and pepper shakers -- actually, she may have received a half dozen or so sets. For some reason, I was unable to get the phrase "salt and pepper shaker" to come out right and if I didn't concentrate, it would come out as "salt and shepper paker." Still sounds better to me!

Let me make the argument against replacing the o in God with a hyphen. I can't speak for Xns but there is /no/ reason for Jews to do so. "God" is not one of the names whose use is limited for Jews. Those are all Hebrew words written in Hebrew characters. Anything in English characters is arguably completely outside the rule. The issue here would probably be pronouncing the crossword answer as written, although even there we have no belief that the inserted vowels in any way relate to the lost sound of the Name.

For most traditional Jews (I'm trying not to pick any specific stream within Judaism), "God" is just an English tag attached to a certain entity or perhaps even more abstractly to an idea. Substituting the hyphen doesn't change the referent. If you changed it to "Gd",  as some people do, it still bears the same referent. So, there is no point in changing the English word in an attempt to preserve some notion of sacredness.

I await the shower of brickbats.

@Daily-Solver

My point is not that the clue and answer of 9D are not technically legal according to crossword rules. They are. 

The question is not whether you could include this word; it’s whether you should. 

I usually say that if it’s in the dictionary, it passes muster, but what if the clues were [Defecate], [Copulate], and [Woman’s genitals], and those answers were the three Anglo-Saxon words of four letters you must realize I’m referring to?  All three are in Merriam-Webster, but would you put any of them in a crossword?  

What’s more, M-W’s definition of 9D is quite wanting. No one knows what full word ancient Hebrews used for God, since Hebrew, then and now, doesn’t normally show vowels in writing. Since the word was only spoken by the Temple High Priest once a year, after the destruction of the Temple the word was never uttered, and its true pronunciation forgotten. 

Observant Jews write YHWH or YHVH or the Hebrew letters yod-he-vav-he, and use it only in prayer and scholarly work, and never try to pronounce it. They speak to God using “Adonai” (my Lord) and speak of God as “HaShem” (The Name).  

Some observant Jews would rather (and have; see Pax’s comment) quit the puzzle than write in 9D to solve the puzzle. 

I hope this clarifies things better for you.
